title: What is the power series of (x^2-4) y”+3xy’+y=0? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why would you want a power series when you can solve this outright in closed form? Just notice that [math](x^2-4)'' = 2[/math] and [math](3x)' = 3[/math], so [math]1 = (3x)' - (x^2-4)''[/math]. The coefficient for [math]y[/math] is also [math]1[/math], so we can make that substitution to get a new form of the equation [math]\displaystyle (x^2-4)y'' - (x^2-4)''y + (3x)y' + (3x)'y = 0[/math] You should be getting some very product rule vibes from this, especially those last two terms, which are clearly an expansion of [math](3xy)'[/math]. The first two terms are a bit more difficult, so let’s write out the product rule for second derivatives [math]\displaystyle (fg)'' = f''g + 2f'g' + fg''[/math] Now we can manipulate the right hand side to get something that looks like the first two terms in our equation [math]\displaystyle (fg)'' - 2f'g' - 2f''g = fg'' - f''g[/math] and then notice the other product rule that cropped up in the second and third terms [math]\displaystyle (fg)'' - 2(f'g)' = fg'' - f''g[/math] Now use this new “rule” to rewrite the first two terms of our equation [math]\displaystyle ((x^2-4)y)'' - 2((x^2-4)'y)' + (3xy)' = 0[/math] Combine the two first derivatives and move them to the right side of the equation [math]\displaystyle ((x^2-4)y)'' = (xy)'[/math] Since there’s an extra derivative on each side, we can just integrate it off [math]\displaystyle ((x^2-4)y)' = c_1 + xy[/math] Now we can unwrap that product rule on the left and rearrage a bit [math]\displaystyle (x^2-4)y' + xy = c_1[/math] And one more time, we’re gonna use the product rule. But since it’s not a product rule by itself, we need to multiply by something that will make it a product rule, which is [math]\displaystyle \frac{1}{x^2-4}\exp\int \frac{x}{x^2-4} \text dx = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}[/math] So we divide everything by [math]\sqrt{x^2-4}[/math] to get [math]\displaystyle \sqrt{x^2-4}y' + \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}y = \frac{c_1}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}[/math] Now we can actually use that product rule [math]\displaystyle (\sqrt{x^2-4}y)' = \frac{c_1}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}[/math] Then just integrate off the derivative and divide by [math]\sqrt{x^2-4}[/math] again [math]\displaystyle \int (\sqrt{x^2-4}y)' \text dx = \int \frac{c_1}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}\text dx[/math] [math]\displaystyle \sqrt{x^2-4}y = c_1\log(\sqrt{x^2-4}+x) + c_2 [/math] [math]\displaystyle y = \frac{c_1\log(\sqrt{x^2-4}+x) + c_2}{\sqrt{x^2-4}} = c_1\frac{\log(\sqrt{x^2-4}+x)}{\sqrt{x^2-4}} + c_2\frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-4}}[/math]
